properties.media:imagetext:
AROUND THE WORLD
VIA GUAM
176-1976
On June, 1946, a crowd of 5,000 bid farewell to
the Pan
American World Airways "Clipper
America"
as it set out from New York on the
first regularly scheduled around-the-world com-
mercial plane flight. Fitted out with forty-four
fully reclining seats as well as pullman-type fold-
down berths, the new Lockheed Constellation rose
to 20,000 feet to reach its cruising speed of 325
miles an hour and speed towards its first stop at
Gander, Newfoundland.
The crew of 10 and their 19 VIP passengers
(including PAN AM president Juan T. Trippe)
flew on to visit Shannon, London, Istanbul,
Dharan, Karachi, Calcutta, Bangkok, Manila,
Shanghai and Tokyo before arriving at Guam.
While they had expected to be on Guam only long
enough for a leisurely breakfast,
the plane
developed engine trouble soon after taking off
and had to return to the island for minor repairs.
Taking
advantage of the brief delay, the
passengers were treated to a tour of the island by
Admiral Pownall,
the military governor of
Guam. In addition to the scenic beauty of the
island, the sights that impressed them most were
the evidence of the frightful waste of the recent
war: hundreds of white crosses marched rank by
rank to the edge of the jungle in a military
cemetery and everywhere quonset huts and even
fields were filled with now surplus war supplies
of every description.

«OUTION
GEN
AROUND THE WORLD
VIA GUAM
1776-191°
On June, 1946, a crowd of 5,000 bid farewell to
the Pan American World Airways "Clipper
America" as it set out from New York on the
first regularly scheduled around-the-world com-
mercial plane flight. Fitted out with forty-four
fully reclining seats as well as pullman-type fold-
down berths, the new Lockheed Constellation rose
to 20.000 feet to reach its cruising speed of 325
miles an hour and speed towards its first stop at
Gander, Newfoundland.
The crew of 10 and their 19 VIP passengers
(including PAN AM president Juan T. Trippe)
flew on to visit Shannon. London, Istanbul.
Dharan, Karachi, Calcutta, Bangkok, Manila,
Shanghai and Tokyo before arriving at Guam.
While they had expected to be on Guam only long
enough for a leisurely breakfast, the plane
developed engine trouble soon after taking off
and had to return to the island for minor repairs.
Taking advantage of the brief delay, the
passengers were treated to a tour of the island by
Admiral Pownall, the military governor of
Guam. In addition to the scenic beauty of the
island, the sights that impressed them most were
the evidence of the frightful waste of the recent
war: hundreds of white crosses marched rank by
rank to the edge of the jungle in a military
cemetery and everywhere quonset huts and even
fields were filled with now surplus war supplies
of every description.

Their plane was soon ready for takeoff once
again and they reached Wake Island in time for
dinner that evening. The rest of their trip was
uneventful as they flew on to Midway, Honolulu,
San Francisco and Chicago before arriving at
New York. In a little over 13 days (101 hours 32
minutes of actual flight time) they had visited 10
different countries in completing their epic
22,297 mile journey that ushered in a new era for
commercial aviation.
2000-058.1257 b
